docTitle.titlePart: THURSDAY EVENING A Comedy in One Act By Christopher Morley

sp.speaker: THURSDAY EVENING
sp.p: SCENE A small suburban kitchen in the modest home of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon Johns . A meal has recently been cooked , as is shown by a general confusion of pots and pans and dish-cloths . At the rear , an icebox standing in the corner . Rear , center , two shelved cabinets , one containing groceries and household sundries , the other dishes and glassware . Rear , L , an oil range . Some baby linen and very small shirtssuch as would be suitable for a child of about ten months ’are hanging on a clothes-horse near the stove . Boor R leads out to back porch ; there are two windows in R wall , one each side of door . Door L to diningroom . At the corner in the rear , L , door opening on back stairs , which ascend to upper parts of the house . Down stage , L , against side wall , a sink and oil-cloth covered drain-board or shelf beside it . In the center of stage a small table covered with oil-cloth . A kitchen chair in corner , down R . When the scene opens , GORDON and LAURA are carrying in soiled dishes through door , L. They come in and out several times , making methodical arrangements for cleaning up . They pile the dishes on the shelf by the sink . Gordon takes dishpan from a hook under the sink , and fills it with hot water from the kettle on the stove . LAURA , who is an attractive little person , aged about twenty-three , is in that slightly tense condition of a young hostess who has had a long and trying day with house and baby , and has also cooked and served a dinner for four .

sp.speaker: GORDON
sp.p: All right , Creature , just wait till I light my pipe and we 'll polish this up .Lights pipe and rolls up shirtsleeves .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: taking an apron from chair in cornerPut this on first . That 's the only decent pair of trousers you 've got .

sp.speaker: MRS. SHEFF
sp.p: Now you children run along and take it easy . I 'll do all this .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: No , no , mother . You go and talk to Mrs. Johns .Pointedly .Do n't let her come in here . mrs. sheffultramaternallyPoor baby , she 's tired . You 've been on your feet all day , now let Mother wash up for you . That was a big dinner to cook .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: No tireder than you are , Mother darling . You cooked lunch .

sp.speaker: GORDON
sp.p: Both of you clear out ; I can get this done in no time .

sp.speaker: MRS. SHEFF
sp.p: patting Laura 's cheekBusy with the baby all afternoon , and then cooking such a delicious dinner — Dearie , wo n't you let Mother do this for you ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: There is n't room in this kitchen for everybody —Enter Mrs. Johns , carrying dishes .

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHNS
sp.p: Gordon , you and Laura go and rest . Let the two grandmothers —

sp.speaker: GORDON
sp.p: Now listen , little people , this is my job . I always wash up on Thursday evenings —

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHNS
sp.p: You go and read your newspaper . I can see you 're all fagged out after that long day in the office —

sp.speaker: MRS. SHEFF
sp.p: to LauraPlease go and lie down , Baby . You 're so tired .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: with waning patienceYou two go and amuse yourselves ; Gordon and I 'll attend to this .They gently eject the two mothers-in-law .

sp.speaker: GORDON
sp.p: Come on , now , the good old system !He takes the small table from center of stage , and puts it carefully midway between sink and dish cabinet . Takes chair from corner , down R , and sets it beside table . Laura sits down on chair and wipes silverware and dishes as he hands them to her after washing .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: The silver first , while the water 's clean .

sp.speaker: GORDON
sp.p: Right . We make a pretty good team at this , do n't we ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: holds up a small silver jugThat darling old cream jug . Mother used that when she was a little girl .

sp.speaker: GORDON
sp.p: I love our little Thursday evening suppers . I think they 're more fun than any other night .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: I 'm glad , Gordie .

sp.speaker: GORDON
sp.p: We get better grub on Thursdays , when Ethel goes out , than we ever do when she 's in .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: I tried to have everything specially nice tonight . Some visitors are very critical .

sp.speaker: GORDON
sp.p: It was lovely . I 'm afraid it was hard for you , Creature , to have Mother come just now .A short pause ,Especially when your Mother was here .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Did n't she know Mother was here ?

sp.speaker: GORDON
sp.p: No . I had n't told her . You see your Mother is here so much more often . I did n't know your mother would still be here . I was afraid Mother might be a little hurt —

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Mother helps me a great deal . I think it 's a queer thing if a wife can n't have her mother stay with her once in a while —

sp.speaker: GORDON
sp.p: aware of danger , changes the subjectYe Gods , Ethel has cracked the Copenhagen platter .Laura is silent .That 's one of the set Mother gave us when we were married .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: It 's a stock pattern . You can get another at any department store .

sp.speaker: GORDON
sp.p: I 'll bet that coon did n't empty the icebox pan before she went . I never saw a cook yet who could remember to do that —

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: If you had to go out and hunt for them you would n't be so particular . She 's better than no one .

sp.speaker: GORDON
sp.p: goes to icebox and removes a large , brimming pan from under itWhat did I tell you !The water slops over from pan as he carries it gingerly to sink and empties it . He replaces the pan under icebox .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: You 'd better heat some more water . You 've poured that ice-water into the dishpan .

sp.speaker: GORDON
sp.p: getting a little peevish ; refills kettle and puts it on stoveIt 's perfectly absurd not having any pantry to keep the icebox in . In here , the heat of the stove melts the ice right away .Goes back to icebox and slams its doors shut .Of course , she never keeps the doors properly closed .He returns to sink and resumes dishwashing .It 's a funny thing .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: What is ?

sp.speaker: GORDON
sp.p: Why , that a presumably intelligent coon can n't understand the doors of an icebox are meant to be kept tight shut , to save ice . What does she suppose those little clamps are for ?Laura is silent . There is a pause , while Gordon scrapes portions of food off the soiled plates . He examines some of these plates rather carefully , and picks out several large pieces of meat , lettuce , butter , etc . which he puts on one plate at one side . Then he seems to resume his good humor and relights his pipe .Well , it 's jolly to have both the grandmothers here together , is n't it ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Gordon , dear , put the silver away in the sideboard before it gets wet again .He gathers up silver from the table in front of her and exit L. Laura steps outside door R , and returns , bringing garbage can , which she puts down by the sink . She begins to wash dishes , and sees the plate of odds and ends which Gordon has carefully put to one side . She scrapes its contents into the garbage pail . While she is washings Gordon enter , L .

sp.speaker: GORDON
sp.p: Now , Creature , let me do that . You do n't want to spoil those pretty hands .Takes them , with an attempt to be affectionate .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: I guess it is n't any worse for them than washing the baby 's things .

sp.speaker: GORDON
sp.p: Come on , old man , let me .Gently removes her from sink , and pushes her to the chair by the table . She sits down and wipes dishes as he hands them to her .It does n't take long when there are two of us .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Gordie , these dishes are n't properly clean . You can n't get that grease off without hot water .

sp.speaker: GORDON
sp.p: I guess that kettle 's hot by now .To stove , feels water in kettle .Give it a minute longer .Stands by stove and puffs at his pipe . In a moment of false security , he foolishly reopens a dangerous topic .You know , I 'm a little worried about Mother .

lg.l: I do n't think she 's as well as usual . She hardly ate any of her salad .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: turns as though about to say somethings but checks herself and pauses a moment . This time it is she who tries honorably to avert the gathering stormOh , Gordie , I forgot to tell you ! Junior drank out of a cup to-day — the first time !

sp.speaker: GORDON
sp.p: He did ! The little rascal !

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Look , here 's the cup .Shows a small silver cup .

sp.speaker: GORDON
sp.p: affectionately , putting his arm around herWell , well .Looks at cup .What cup is that ? I do n't seem to remember it —

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Why — Mother brought it with her . She used it when she was a baby .

sp.speaker: GORDON
sp.p: Where 's that nice old Christening mug of mine ? I think Junior would like to use that once in a while , too .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: I put it away , dear . I was afraid Ethel might dent it .

sp.speaker: GORDON
sp.p: takes kettle from stove , goes back to sinkI hope Mother is n't feeling poorly . I noticed at supper —

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: When hot meat is served , refined people usually call it dinner —

sp.speaker: GORDON
sp.p: looks at her cautiously , and suddenly seems to realize that they are on the edge of an abyssNow , honey , you 're tired . You go and rest , I 'll finish up here .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: No , thank you . I like to see that everything gets cleaned up properly . Someone might come snooping out here , and then there 'd be hints about my housekeeping . Of course , I 'll admit I was n't brought up to be a cook —

sp.speaker: GORDON
sp.p: seeks inspiration by relighting his pipe , and takes up a handsome silver coffee potOne thing I never can make out is , how to prevent coffee grounds from going down the sink .He talks desperately , trying to tide over the mutually realized danger point .Perhaps if I could invent some kind of a little coffee-ground strainer I 'd make our fortune . That coffee was delicious , Creature .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Take care of that urn , it 's one of the few handsome things we have .

sp.speaker: GORDON
sp.p: It is a beauty .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Jack Davis gave it to me —

sp.speaker: GORDON
sp.p: puts it down with distasteI guess I 'd better attend to the garbage .

sp.speaker: It 's all fixed
sp.p: GORDON I always like Thursdays because that 's the one evening Ethel does n't get a chance to throw away about five dollars ’ worth of good food .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: I fixed the garbage . You can put the pail outside .

sp.speaker: GORDON
sp.p: hunting among plates on the shelf beside sinkWhere 's that plate I put here ? There was a lot of perfectly good stuff I saved —

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: blows up at lastWell , if you think I 'm going to keep a lot of halfeaten salad your Mother picked over —

sp.speaker: GORDON
sp.p: seizes garbage pail , lifts it up to the sink and begins to explore its contents . His fuse also is rapidly shortening .My Lord , it 's no wonder we never have any money to spend if we chuck half of it away in waste .Picking out various selections .Waste ! Look at that piece of cheese , and those potatoes . You could take those things , and some of this meat , and make a nice economical hash for lunch —

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: It 's a wonder you would n't get a job as a scavenger . I never heard of a husband like you , rummaging through the garbage pail .

sp.speaker: GORDON
sp.p: blows upDo you know what the one unforgivable sin is ? The sin against the Holy Ghost ? It 's Waste ! It makes me wild to think of working and working like a dog , and half of what I earn just thrown away by an ignorant coon . Look at this , just look at it !Displays a grisly object .There 's enough meat on that bone to make soup . And ye gods , here 's that jar of anchovy paste !Holds it up .I thought you got that for me as a little treat . I wondered where it had gone to . Why , I had n't eaten more than just the top of it .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Well , you left it , and left it , and it got mildewed .

sp.speaker: GORDON
sp.p: Scrape it off . A little mildew wo n't hurt anybody . There 'll be mildew on my bank account if this kind of thing goes on .Still examining garbage pail .Look here , about half a dozen slices of bread . What 's the matter with them , I 'd like to know .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: I think it 's the most disgusting thing I ever heard of . To go picking over the garbage pail like that . You attend to your affairs and I 'll attend to mine .

sp.speaker: GORDON
sp.p: I guess throwing away good , hard-earned money is my affair , is n't it ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: You 're always quick enough to find fault . I know Ethel 's careless , but she 's the best I can get out here in this godforsaken suburb . Maybe you 'll be good enough to find me a better servant . A well-trained girl would n't work in this old dump , where there is n't even gas . You do n't seem to know when you 're lucky . You come back at night and find your home well cared for and me slaving over a hot dinner , and do you ever say a word of thanks ? No , all you can think of is finding fault . I can n't imagine how you were brought up . Your Mother —

sp.speaker: GORDON
sp.p: Just leave my mother out of it . I guess she did n't spoil me the way yours did you . Of course , I was n't an only daughter —

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: I wish you had been . Then I would n't have married you .

sp.speaker: GORDON
sp.p: I suppose you think that if you 'd married Jack Davis or some other of those profiteers you 'd never have had to see the inside of a kitchen —

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: If Junior grows up with your disposition , all I can say is , I hope he 'll never get married .

sp.speaker: GORDON
sp.p: If he gets married , I hope it 'll be to some girl who understands something about economy —

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: If he gets married , I hope he 'll be man enough not to be always finding fault —

sp.speaker: GORDON
sp.p: Well , he wo n't get married ! I 'll put him wise to what marriage means , fussing like this all the time —

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Yes , he will get married . He shall get married !

sp.speaker: GORDON
sp.p: Oh , this is too absurd —

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: He shall get married , just to be a humiliating example to his father . I 'll bring him up the way a husband ought to be .

sp.speaker: GORDON
sp.p: In handcuffs , I suppose —

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: And his wife wo n't have to sit and listen to perpetual criticism from his mother —

sp.speaker: GORDON
sp.p: If you 're so down on mothers-in-law , it 's queer you 're anxious to be one yourself . The expectant mother-in-law !

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: All right , be vulgar . I dare say you can n't help it .

sp.speaker: GORDON
sp.p: Great Scott , what did you think marriage was like , anyway ? Did you expect to go through life having everything done for you , without a little hard work to make it interesting ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Is it necessary to shout ?

sp.speaker: GORDON
sp.p: Now let me tell you something . Let 's see if you can ratify it from your extensive observation of life . Is there anything in the world so cruel as bringing up a girl in absolute ignorance of housework , believing that all her days she 's going to be waited on hand and foot , and that marriage is one long swoon of endearments —

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: There 's not much swooning while you 're around .

sp.speaker: GORDON
sp.p: Why , I believe you actually think your life is wrecked if you are n't being petted and praised every minute . You pretend to think marriage is so sacred and yet you 're buffaloed by a few greasy dishes . I like my kind of sacredness better than yours , and that 's the sacredness of common sense . Marriage ought not to be performed before an altar , but before a kitchen sink .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: furiouslyI ought to have known that oil and water wo n't mix . I ought to have known that a vulgar , selfish , conceited man could n't make a girl happy who was brought up in a refined family . I was a Sheffield , and why I ever became a Johns is more than I can imagine , Johns — I suppose that 's camouflage for Jones . You 're too common , too ordinary , to know when you 're lucky . You get a charming aristocratic wife and expect her to grub along like a washerwoman . You try to crush all the life and spirit out of her . You ought to have married an icebox — that 's the only thing in this house you 're really attentive to .

sp.speaker: GORDON
sp.p: Now listen —

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: will not be checkedTalk about being spoiled — why , your Mother babies you so , you think you 're the only man on earth .Sarcastically .Her poor , overworked boy , who tries so hard and gets all fagged out in the office and struggles so nobly to support his family ! I wonder how you 'd like to run this house and bear a child and take care of it and shuffle along with an ignorant coon for a maid and then cook a big dinner and be sneered at and never a word of praise . All you can think of is picking over the garbage pail and finding fault —

sp.speaker: GORDON
sp.p: like a foolI did n't find fault . I found some good food being wasted .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: All right , if you love the garbage pail better than you do your wife , you can live with it .Flings her dishtowel on the floor and exit , L .

body.stage: Gordon stands irresolutely at the sink , and makes a few gloomy motions among the unfinished dishes . He glares at the garbage can . Then he carefully gathers those portions of food that he had chosen as being still usable , contemplates them grimly , then puts them on a plate and , after some hesitation , puts the plate in the icebox . He takes the garbage can and puts it outside door , R. He returns into the kitchen , but then a sudden fit of anger seizes him .

lg.stage: Tears off apron , throws it on the floor , and exit R , slamming door .

body.stage: After a brief pause , the door at the rear opening onto the back stairs , is cautiously opened , and Mrs. Sheffield enters quietly . She takes one swift look around the disordered kitchen , picks up dishtowel and apron from the floor , and sets to work rapidly to clean up . Then the back stairs door is again opened in the same stealthy way , and Mrs. Johns enters . The two ladies seem to take each other 's measure with instinctive shrewdness , and fall into a silent , businesslike team-play in putting things to rights . Mrs. Johns takes charge at the sink , and the remaining dishes spin under her capable hands . Mrs. Sheffield takes them from her , rapidly polishes them , and puts them away on the shelves . There is unconscious comedy in the trained precision and labor-saving method of their actions , which are synchronized so that every time Mrs. Johns holds out a washed dish , Mrs. Sheffield is moving back from the cabinet , ready to receive it . They work like automatons , for perhaps two minutes not a word is said , and the two seem , by searching side-glances , to be probing each other 's mood .

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHNS
sp.p: If it was n't so tragic I 'd laugh .A pause , during which they work busily .

sp.speaker: MRS. SHEFF
sp.p: If it was n't so comic I 'd cry .Another pause .I guess it 's my fault . Poor Laura , I 'm afraid I have spoiled her .

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHNS
sp.p: My fault , I think . Two mothers-in-law at once is too much for any young couple . I did n't know you were here , or I would n't have come .

sp.speaker: MRS. SHEFF
sp.p: Laura is so dreadfully sensitive , poor child —

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHNS
sp.p: Gordon works so hard at the office . You know he 's trying to get promoted to the sales department , and I suppose it tells on his nerves —

sp.speaker: MRS. SHEFF
sp.p: If Laura could afford to have a nurse to help her with the baby she would n't get so exhausted —

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHNS
sp.p: Gordon says he wants to take out some more insurance , that 's why he worries so about economy . It is n't for himself , he 's really very unselfish —

sp.speaker: MRS. SHEFF
sp.p: a little tartlyStill , I do think that sometimes —They pause and look at each other quickly .My gracious , we 'll be at it ourselves if we do n't look out !

body.stage: She goes to the clothes-horse and rearranges the garments on it . She holds up a lilliputian shirt , and they both smile .

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHNS
sp.p: That darling baby ! I hope he wo n't have poor Gordon 's quick temper . It runs in the Johns family , I 'm afraid . I was an Armstrong before I married Gordon 's father — I did n't know what temper was until I married — either my own or his .

sp.speaker: MRS. SHEFF
sp.p: I was a Thomson — Thomson without the P , you know , from Rhode Island . All families are hot tempered . All husbands ’ families , anyway .

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHNS
sp.p: Gordon 's father used to say that Adam and Eve did n't know when they were well off . He said that was why they called it the Garden of Eden .

sp.speaker: MRS. SHEFF
sp.p: Why ?

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHNS
sp.p: Because there was no mother-in-law there .

sp.speaker: MRS. SHEFF
sp.p: Poor children , they have such a lot to learn ! I really feel ashamed , Mrs. Johns , because Laura is an undisciplined little thing , and I 'm afraid I 've always petted her too much . She had such a lot of attention before she met Gordon , and was made so much of , it gave her wrong ideas .

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHNS
sp.p: I wish Gordon was a little younger , I 'd like to turn him up and spank him . He 's dreadfully stubborn and tactless —

sp.speaker: MRS. SHEFF
sp.p: But I 'm afraid I did make a mistake . Laura was having such a good time as a girl , I was always afraid she 'd have a hard awakening when she married . But Mr. Sheffield had a good deal of money at that time , and he used to say , ‘ She 's only young once , let her enjoy herself . ’

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHNS
sp.p: My husband was shortsighted , too . He had had to skimp so , that he brought up Gordon to have a terror of wasting a nickel .

sp.speaker: MRS. SHEFF
sp.p: Very sensible . I wish Mr. Sheffield had had a little more of that terror . I shall have to tell him what his policy has resulted in . But really , you know , when I heard them at it , I could hardly help admiring them .With a sigh .It brings back old times !

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHNS
sp.p: So it does !A pause .But we can n't let them go on like this . A little vigorous quarreling is good for everybody . It 's a kind of spiritual laxative . But they carry it too far .

sp.speaker: MRS. SHEFF
sp.p: They 're awfully ingenious . They were even bickering about Junior 's future mother-in-law . I suppose she 's still in school , whoever she may be !

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHNS
sp.p: Being a mother-in-law is almost as painful as being a mother .

sp.speaker: MRS. SHEFF
sp.p: I think every marriage ought to be preceded by a treaty of peace between the two mothers . If they understand each other , everything will work out all right .

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHNS
sp.p: You 're right . When each one takes sides with her own child , it 's fatal .

sp.speaker: MRS. SHEFF
sp.p: lowering her voiceLook here , I think I know how we can make them ashamed of themselves . Where are they now ?

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHNS
sp.p: goes cautiously to door L and peeps throughLaura is lying on the couch in the living-room . I think she 's crying — her face is buried in the cushions .

sp.speaker: MRS. SHEFF
sp.p: Splendid . That means she 's listening with all her ears —Tiptoes to window , R .I can n't see Gordon , but I think he 's walking round the garden —

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHNS
sp.p: quietlyIf we were to talk a little louder he 'd sit on the back steps to hear it —

sp.speaker: MRS. SHEFF
sp.p: Exactly . Now listen !They put their heads together and whisper ; the audience does not hear what is said .

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHNS
sp.p: Fine ! Oh , that 's fine !Mrs. Sheffield whispers again , inaudible to the spectators .But wait a moment . Do n't you think it would be better if I praise Laura and you praise Gordon ? They wo n't expect that , and it might shame them —

sp.speaker: MRS. SHEFF
sp.p: No , no ! Do n't you see —Whispers again , inaudibly .

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHNS
sp.p: You 're right . Cunning as serpents and harmless as doves —They carefully set both doors , L and R ajar .

sp.speaker: MRS. SHEFF
sp.p: I only hope we wo n't wake the baby —They return to the task of cleaning up , and talk very loudly in pretended quarrel .

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHNS
sp.p: Where do these dessert plates go ?

sp.speaker: MRS. SHEFF
sp.p: On this shelf .

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHNS
sp.p: You 're here so much more often than I , naturally you know Laura 's arrangements better .

sp.speaker: MRS. SHEFF
sp.p: It 's a lucky thing I am here . I do n't know what poor Laura would do without me at such a dreadful time —

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHNS
sp.p: Poor Laura ! I should say she 's very fortunate , such a good husband —

sp.speaker: MRS. SHEFF
sp.p: I think it 's rather sad for a girl who has had as much as she has , to come down to this —

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHNS
sp.p: It 's perfectly wonderful how Gordon has got on in business —

sp.speaker: MRS. SHEFF
sp.p: He ought to , with such a lovely home , run like a clock —

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHNS
sp.p: Yes . An alarm clock .

sp.speaker: MRS. SHEFF
sp.p: Well , I 'm not going to see my daughter 's happiness ruined —

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHNS
sp.p: I always knew he 'd make some girl a fine husband —

sp.speaker: MRS. SHEFF
sp.p: Perhaps . But he seems to have picked the wrong girl . Laura has too much spirit to be bullied —

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHNS
sp.p: Well , perhaps it was all a mistake . Poor Gordon , he works so hard . I believe his hair is going white over his ears already .

sp.speaker: MRS. SHEFF
sp.p: Stuff ! That 's lather from where he shaved this morning . He 's too slovenly to wash it off .

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHNS
sp.p: It is n't right that a young man should have to slave the way he does —

sp.speaker: MRS. SHEFF
sp.p: apparently in a passionDo you think that business slavery can compare to household slavery ? I think it 's heartrending to see an attractive girl like Laura shut up in a poky little house doing drudgery and tending a baby . Think of it , having to take care of her own baby ! Why , it 's an outrage . If Gordon was half a man , he 'd get her a trained baby nurse so she would n't have to look at the poor little thing —

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHNS
sp.p: scathingYes , how sad that Gordon should have to entrust his son to amateur care when it needs scientific attention .

sp.speaker: MRS. SHEFF
sp.p: Poor darling Laura — she never ought to have had a baby .

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHNS
sp.p: Gordon is too intellectual to be bothered with these domestic details . He ought to be able to concentrate on his work .

sp.speaker: MRS. SHEFF
sp.p: coming close to Mrs. Johns , feigning great rage , but grimacing to show it is merely actingWell , if you do n't think my daughter is good enough for your son , I can always take her home with me . I guess I can find room for her , and we can put the child in an institution .Both nearly laughs but recover themselves .

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHNS
sp.p: Do n't worry . I 'll take the child . He 's a Johns anyway , not a Sheffield . And you just watch Gordon , when he 's relieved of all this family worry and quarreling . He 'll make his mark in the world . He 's too fine to be tied down by a wife that does n't understand him .

sp.speaker: MRS. SHEFF
sp.p: Oh , how happy Laura will be to hear this . My sweet , clever , attractive , economical , sensible little girl , free at last . Her married life has been a nightmare . That great , hulking , selfish man has tried to trample all the joy out of her . He sha n't do it .

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHNS
sp.p: I never heard of a young husband as self-sacrificing as Gordon . I do n't believe he ever goes out for an evening with other men , and he never spends anything on himself —

sp.speaker: MRS. SHEFF
sp.p: I think the way Laura runs her little home is just wonderful . See how she struggles to keep her kitchen in order — this miserable , inconvenient little kitchen , no gas , no pantry , no decent help . I think it 's terrible she has had to put up with so much —They pause , and listen at the door , L. The kitchen is now spick and span . Mrs. Johns makes a gesture to indicate that Laura is taking it all in , offstage .

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHNS
sp.p: Well , then , it 's all settled .

sp.speaker: MRS. SHEFF
sp.p: Yes . As Laura 's mother , I can n't let her go on like this . A husband , a home , and a baby — it 's enough to ruin any woman .

sp.speaker: MRS. JOHNS
sp.p: It 's only fair to both sides to end it all . I never heard of such brutal hardships . Gordon can n't fight against these things any longer . Throwing away a soupbone and three slices of bread ! I wonder he does n't go mad .

sp.speaker: MRS. SHEFF
sp.p: We 've saved them just in time .They look at each other knowingly , with the air of those who have done a sound bit of work , Then they stealthily open the door at the rear , and exeunt up the back stairs ,

body.stage: There is a brief pause ; then the door L opens like an explosion , and Laura bursts in , She stands for a moment , wild-eyed , stamps her foot in a passion , Then she seizes one of the baby shirts from the rack , and drops into the chair by the table , crying . She buries her head in her arms , concealing the shirt , Enter Gordon , R , He stands uncertainly , evidently feeling like a fool .

sp.speaker: GORDON
sp.p: I 'm sorry , I — I left my pipe in here .Finds it by the sink ,

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: her face still hiddenOh , Gordie , was it all a mistake ?

sp.speaker: GORDON
sp.p: troubled , pats her shoulder tentativelyNow listen , Creature , do n't . You 'll make yourself sick .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: I never thought I 'd hear such things — from my own mother .

sp.speaker: GORDON
sp.p: I never heard such rot . They must be mad , both of them .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Then you were listening , too —

sp.speaker: GORDON
sp.p: Yes . Why , they 're deliberately trying to set us against each other .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: They would n't have dared speak like that if they had known we could hear . Gordon , I do n't think it 's legal —

sp.speaker: GORDON
sp.p: I 'm afraid the law does n't give one much protection against one 's mothers .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: miserablyI guess she 's right . I am spoiled , and I am silly , and I am extravagant —

sp.speaker: GORDON
sp.p: Do n't be silly , darling . That 's crazy stuff . I 'm not overworked , and even if I were I 'd love it , for you —

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: I do n't want a nurse for Junior . I would n't have one in the house .Sits up , dishevelled , and displays the small shirt she has been clutching .Gordon , I 'm not an amateur ! I love that baby and I am scientific . I keep a chart of his weight every week .

sp.speaker: GORDON
sp.p: Yes , I know , ducky , Gordon understands . Soon we 'll be able to buy that scales you want , and we wo n't have to weigh him on the meat balance .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Nobody can take away my darling baby —

sp.speaker: GORDON
sp.p: It was my fault , dear . I am obstinate and disagreeable —

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: I 'll speak to Ethel about the garbage —

sp.speaker: GORDON
sp.p: Ethel 's all right . We 're lucky to have her .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Gordon , you must n't work too hard . You know you 're all I have —A sob .since Mother 's gone back on me .

sp.speaker: GORDON
sp.p: patting herI think it 's frightful , the things they said . What are they trying to do , break up a happy home ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: We are happy , are n't we ?

sp.speaker: GORDON
sp.p: Well , I should say so . Did you ever hear me complain ?Takes her in his arms .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: No , Gordie . It was cruel of them to try to make trouble between us — but , perhaps , some of the things they said —

sp.speaker: GORDON
sp.p: Were true ?—

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Well , not exactly true , dear , but — interesting ! — your mother is right , you do have a hard time , and I 'll try —

sp.speaker: GORDON
sp.p: stops herNo , your mother is right . I 've been a brute —

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: I 'm lucky to have such a husband —They are silent a moment .

sp.speaker: GORDON
sp.p: I suppose you 'll think it an awful anticlimax —

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: What , dear ?

sp.speaker: GORDON
sp.p: Suppose we have something to eat ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: happilyGood idea . Quarreling always makes me hungry .They go to the icebox .I did n't really get any supper to speak of , I was worrying about everything so —

sp.speaker: GORDON
sp.p: opening iceboxYou mean dinner , honey — among refined people !

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Do n't be a tease . Come on , we 'll have a snack —She discovers Gordon s plate of left-overs .

sp.speaker: GORDON
sp.p: Throw out that junk — I was idiotic to save it .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: No , Gordie , you were quite right . We must save everything we can . Four or five heads of lettuce would make a new shirt for Junior .

sp.speaker: Lettuce ?
sp.p: LAURA I mean , if we saved that much , it would make enough money to buy him a new little vest . He 's getting so enormous —She puts plate of left-overs on the table , with some other cold food .

sp.speaker: GORDON
sp.p: There , now , this is better .They sit down at table .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: thoughtfullyYou know , Gordie , we must n't let them know we heard them .

sp.speaker: GORDON
sp.p: No , I suppose not . But it 's hard to forgive that sort of talk .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Even if they did say atrocious things , I think they really love us —

sp.speaker: GORDON
sp.p: We 'll be a bit cold and stand-offish until things blow over .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: complacentlyIf I 'm ever a mother-in-law , I shall try to be very understanding —

sp.speaker: GORDON
sp.p: Yes , Creature . Do you remember why I call you Creature ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Do I not ?

sp.speaker: GORDON
sp.p: There was an adjective omitted , you remember .

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Oh , Gordie , that 's one of the troubles of married life . So many of the nice adjectives seem to get omitted .

sp.speaker: GORDON
sp.p: Motto for married men : Do n't run short of adjectives !— You remember what the adjective was ?

sp.speaker: LAURA
sp.p: Tell me .

sp.speaker: GORDON
sp.p: Adorable , It was an abbreviation for Adorable Creature —Holds her , They are both perfectly happy .I love our little Thursday evenings . laurapartly breaks from his embraceSssh !Listens ,Was that the baby ?
